review.title: Geospatial Narratives and their Spatio-Temporal Dynamics: Commonsense Reasoning for High-level Analyses in Geographic Information Systems
review.abstract: The modelling, analysis, and visualisation of dynamic geospatial phenomena has been identified as a key developmental challenge for next-generation Geographic Information Systems (GIS). In this context, the envisaged paradigmatic extensions to contemporary foundational GIS technology raises fundamental questions concerning the ontological, formal representational, and (analytical) computational methods that would underlie their spatial information theoretic underpinnings.

sections.text: Modelling, analysis and visualisation of dynamic geospatial phenomena has been identified as a key development challenge for the next generation of geographical information systems (GIS). In this context, the planned paradigmatic enhancements of contemporary fundamental GIS technologies raise fundamental questions about the ontological, formal representative and (analytical) computer-aided methods that would underlie their spatial information theory foundations. We present the conceptual overview and architecture for the development of high-level semantic and qualitative analytical capabilities for dynamic geospatial domains, building on formal methods in the areas of common sense, qualitative reasoning, spatial and temporal representation and reasoning, reasoning about actions and change, and computational models of narrative, identifying concrete theoretical and practical challenges that arise in the context of formal reasoning about space, events, actions and changes. On this basis, and against the background of an illustrative scenario that relates spatial dynamics and spatial dynamics.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Geographical information systems (GIS) are confronted with massive quantities of micro and macro levels [Yuunt 1995]. In conventional GIS systems, these data take the form of spatio-temporal databases of precise measurements of environmental characteristics, aerial images, and more recently sensor network databases that store real-time information on natural and artificial processes and phenomena. Within the next generation of GIS systems, the basic information theory modalities for undergoing radical transformations are presented: high-level ontological units such as objects, events, actions, and processes, as well as the ability to model and understand them, are expected to be a native feature of the nextgeneration GIS. Indeed, one of the key development goals in GIS systems of the future is a fundamental paradigmatic shift in the underlying "spatial computer science." Time and GIS time are necessary for the development of GIS.

sections.heading: 2. GEOSPATIAL DYNAMICS: APPLICATION PERSPECTIVES
sections.text: In recent years, modelling and analysis of dynamic spatial phenomena and the integration of time in GIS have become important research topics within the GIS community. Although the representative and analytical apparatus for investigating such phenomena is at best emerging, the topic has been considered an important research focus in GIS [Yuan et al., 2004]. Here we briefly outline some selected areas where the term geospatial dynamics is applicable, and also provide motivating scenarios in the field of urban dynamics and environmental development.

sections.heading: 2.1. Application Areas
sections.text: This is a classical domain of application, which, from a spatial perspective, involves the study of diffuse processes (e.g. the spread of diseases) with point-based or aggregated units in space and time. § Moving Data Analysis. This area includes the analysis of (typically human-centric) movement data for the purpose of predicting and explaining. For example, studies involving vehicle / human trajectories, transport data, and crime statistics have received significant attention in this area. § Land use analysis. This corresponds to the analysis of land use patterns, e.g. in urban areas, based on remote sensing and other soil data. One goal here may be to investigate the nature of land use dynamics, either together or in isolation with data that include socio-economic dimensions.

sections.heading: 4. THE SPATIAL INFORMATICS OF GEOSPATIAL DYNAMICS
sections.text: The spatial information theory challenges underlying the development of high-level analytical skills in dynamic GIS consist of fundamental representative and computational problems related to: the semantics of spatial events, the practical hijacking in GIS, and to support these problems of data abstraction, integration, and spatial consistency.

sections.heading: 4.1. Spatial Occurrences: Analyses with Events and Objects
sections.text: Our goal is to develop the functionality that makes it possible to think about spatio-temporal narratives that consist of events and processes at the geographical level. We are not trying to perform an elaborate ontological characterization of events and processes, a research topic that has been extensively explored in the research. For the purposes of this paper, we are using a minimal but rich conceptual model that consists of a series of events, so that it can be used for qualitatively grounded metric spatial datasets that consist of spatial and temporal footprints of human and natural phenomena on a geographical scale.Spatial events can be defined on two levels: (I) domain independent and (II) domain dependent:

sections.heading: I. Domain Independent Spatial Occurrences.
sections.text: These events are those that can be semantically characterized within a general theory of space and spatial change. They can be grounded either in terms of a qualitative theory or an elaborate typology of geospatial events (e.g. Fig. 4 illustrates a typology of changes at the object level). Spatial changes at a qualitative level (relationship) can be regulated as (possibly) by the continuity constraints of the relationship space. At this level, the only identifiable concept of an event is a transition from a qualitative state (relationship) to a state (relationship) other than (possibly) regulated by the continuity constraints of the relationship space. At this level, the only identifiable concept of an event is the qualitative spatial transition to which the primitive objects in theory are subject, e.g. the transition of an object to an object (o1) from separation to another object (o2) to a tangentially appropriate part.

sections.heading: II. Domain-Specific Spatial Occurrences
sections.text: On a domain-dependent level, behavioral patterns can characterize high-level processes, environmental / natural and human activities such as deforestation, urbanization, land-use transformations, etc. These are domain-specific events that trigger a transformation of the underlying spatial structures that can be modeled [Couclelis, 2009]. Essentially, however, these are domain-specific events or actions that exhibit (explicitly) identifiable event criteria and effects that can be defined in terms of qualitative spatial changes, and the basic typology of spatial changes. For example, in Fig. 5, we can clearly see that a region continues to shrink and ultimately disappear during the years 1950 to 1990. Bhatt and Loke [2008] identifies the following general notion of a "spatial event": "spatial events are events or actions with explicitly specifiable event-type events and preconditions and impacts that cause spatial change.

sections.heading: 4.2. Practical Abduction for GIS
sections.text: In the context of formal spatio-temporal calculations and logic of action and change, this means the ability to provide scenario and narrative completion capabilities at a high level of abstraction. Consider the GIS domain depicted in Fig. 5 and the fundamental conceptual understanding of spatial events described in Section 4.1. At a domain-independent level, the scene can be described on the basis of topological and qualitative scale relationships. Consequently, the only changes identifiable at the level of spatial theory are shrinkage and eventual disappearance - this is because a domain-independent spatial theory can only encompass a generic typology (appearance, disappearance, growth, shrinkage, deformation, splitting, merging, etc.) that is independent of spatial changes. However, at a domain-specific level, these changes could designate a particular event (or process) as intuitively explainable or inexplicable.

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Scenario and Narrative Completion
sections.text: Explanatory problems require the inclusion of a narrative description that, from a logic-based point of view, essentially represents a differentiated course of actual events about which we may have incomplete information [Miller and Shanahan, 1994, Pinto, 1998]. Narrative descriptions are typically available as observations from the real / imagined execution of a system or process. Since narratives inherently belong to actual observations, i.e. they are temporally limited, the goal is often to assimilate / explain them in relation to an underlying process model and an approach to deriving explanations.In the face of partial narratives that describe the evolution of a system (e.g. through temporally ordered scene observations in event-based GIS datasets) in relation to spatio-temporal dates, scenarios, and narrative completion of the narrative corresponds to the ability to derive completions that structure the narrative by interpolating the missing spatial and action-situational information / events in a spatial-situation / specific way in a dynamic domaination6.

sections.heading: 4.3.1. Temporal Partitioning and Qualitative Abstraction
sections.text: In the geographical area, input data often comes from multiple sources, such as different sensors, remote sensing data, map data, etc., and the data itself is fraught with measurement errors and uncertainties. In order to perform explanatory analyses on a level of qualitative spatial relations, geo-referenced quantitative input data on spatial objects from different sources must be translated into relationships from several qualitative spatial models or calculations dealing with different aspects of space. A prerequisite for applying the qualitative abstraction method is that the input data is distributed in such a way that each part is linked to a certain point in time in an ordered sequence of time. At each point in time, the qualitative abstraction method takes the associated quantitative data and derives the spatial relations from the given qualitative models that exist between the objects involved, resulting in a static qualitative spatial description for each point in time.

sections.heading: 4.3.3. Conflict Resolution
sections.text: As indicated in the previous section, when conflicts arise during the integration of spatial data, it is often desirable not only to identify the inconsistencies, but also to resolve conflicts in a reasonable manner so as to be able to use all the information provided in the actual logical reasoning approach to explanation and analysis. Methods of data integration and conflict resolution have been investigated, for example, under the terms information fusion Gre ́ goire and Konieczny [2006], and are usually classified into quantitative approaches and symbolic approaches. Quantitative approaches mainly use statistical methods such as Dubai square adjustment to deal with multiple observations, while symbolic information fusion deals with the revision of logical theories in the presence of new evidence. An important distinction here is that between revision and updating. In the case of revision, additional information about a particular state of the world becomes available and must be combined with what was previously known. In the case of updating, it is assumed that the state has changed and that the new information is available as the previous knowledge.

sections.heading: 5. GEOSPATIAL ANALYTICS: A NARRATIVE BASED FORMAL FRAMEWORK
sections.text: Discussions in Section 3 included a number of representative and computational challenges arising in the context of dynamic geospatial analysis. We will now describe our formal framework and associated conceptual architecture for qualitative modeling and high-level explanatory analysis in the field of geospatial dynamics as illustrated in Fig. 9.

sections.heading: 5.1. Overview of Architecture
sections.text: Our proposed architecture encompasses the full range of steps required to perform an explanatory analysis of geospatial dynamics at a qualitative level of abstraction, starting with the processing of the actual (typically quantitative) data to form a unified qualitative description, up to the use of inductive arguments to complete the narrative and to detect high-level processes leading to a knowledge base that can be queried and used by application systems and decision makers. The main aspects of the proposed architecture are the following: - Input data sets. The input consists of data sets from multiple sources such as remote sensing data, spatial databases, sensor data, etc. - Pre-processing. These data sets are then processed to derive qualitative spatial observations linked to specific time points that need to be passed to the actual argumentation components. This pre-processing is done by the partition module, which is responsible for the time module and the integration module.

sections.heading: 6. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION
sections.text: The ability of semantic and qualitative analysis to complement and synergize with statistical and quantitatively driven methods has been recognized within and outside the realm of GIS application areas (discussed in Section 2.1). Researchers in GIS information theory have examined several fundamental ontological aspects of event modeling, such as the practical development of events relevant to a geopolitical context, and the construction of formal methods in qualitative information theory.

Formal methods in QSTR provide a commonsensical interface to abstract and reason about quantitative spatial information. Formal methods in QSTR provide a commonsensical interface to abstract and reason about quantitative spatial information. The common characteristic of the developed formal models, often termed qualitative calculi, is that, in contrast to quantitative approaches, just a small number of basic relations is distinguished. Qualitative spatial / temporal calculi are relational-algebraic systems pertaining to one or more aspects of space. They abstract from metrical details and focus on properties that make a difference in a particular application domain. This allows for an analysis of spatio-temporal data on a high-level of abstraction and directly with respect to human spatio-temporal concepts and commonsense reasoning. As such, they provide one means to represent and analyse data in an abstract way that is more natural to humans, a key challenge identified for future GIS (e.g., Gahegan [1996], Mennis et al. [2000], Peuquet [1988]). The basic tenets in QSTR consist of constraint based reasoning algorithms over an infinite (spatial) domain to solve consistency problems in the context of spatial calculi. The key idea here is to partition an infinite quantity space into finite disjoint categories, and utilise the special relational properties of such a partitioned space for reasoning purposes. In general, qualitative spatial calculi can be classified into two groups: topological and positional calculi. With topological calculi such as the Region Connection Calculus (RCC), the primitive entities are spatially extended regions of space, and could possibly even be 4D spatio-temporal histories, e.g., for motionpattern analyses. Alternatively, within a dynamic domain involving translational motion, point-based abstractions with orientation calculi suffice. Examples of orientation calculi include [Cohn and Renz, 2007]: the Oriented-Point Relation Algebra (OPRAm), the Double-Cross Calculus, and the line-segment based Dipole Calculus. Similar to these works, which are situated within an Artificial Intelligence / Knowledge Representation (KR) context, many crucial advances have accrued from other communities concerned with the development of formalisms and algorithms for modelling and reasoning about spatial information, a prime example here being the domain of spatial information theory for Geographic Information Systems (GIS) [Egenhofer and Mark, 1995, Egenhofer and Franzosa, 1991]. Most widely adopted and applied qualitative spatial (topological) calculi are the RCC-8 calculus Randell et al. Deciding consistency of a set of qualitative spatial relations has been studied as one of the fundamental reasoning tasks in qualitative spatial representation and reasoning [Cohn and Renz, 2007]. The complexity of deciding consistency varies significantly over the different existing qualitative calculi. For most common qualitative calculi such as RCC-8, the consistency can be decided in cubic time when the input description is a scenario which means it does not contain disjunction of relations. This is achieved by the path consistency or algebraic closure method Mackworth [1977] which is ultimately based on a set of composition axioms that state which relation can hold between objects A and C given the relations holding between object A and B and between B and C.

metadata.abstractText: The modelling, analysis, and visualisation of dynamic geospatial phenomena has been identified as a key developmental challenge for next-generation Geographic Information Systems (GIS). In this context, the envisaged paradigmatic extensions to contemporary foundational GIS technology raises fundamental questions concerning the ontological, formal representational, and (analytical) computational methods that would underlie their spatial information theoretic underpinnings. We present the conceptual overview and architecture for the development of high-level semantic and qualitative analytical capabilities for dynamic geospatial domains. Building on formal methods in the areas of commonsense reasoning, qualitative reasoning, spatial and temporal representation and reasoning, reasoning about actions and change, and computational models of narrative, we identify concrete theoretical and practical challenges that accrue in the context of formal reasoning about space, events, actions, and change. With this as a basis, and within the backdrop of an illustrated scenario involving the spatiotemporal dynamics of urban narratives, we address specific problems and solutions techniques chiefly involving qualitative abstraction, data integration and spatial consistency, and practical geospatial abduction. From a broad topical viewpoint, we propose that next-generation dynamic GIS technology demands a transdisciplinary scientific perspective that brings together Geography, Artificial Intelligence, and Cognitive Science.
